Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cross-National Research on Protest, Social Policy, and Political Regimes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this proposal, the PI investigates how redistributive policies within countries vary by regime type. In particular, the study focuses on how governments target redistributive actions to favor specific groups they see as important supporters. To explore how regime types matter, the proposal compares decisions regarding redistributive policy in one authoritarian country and one country transitioning to democracy. While both states experienced notable stress resulting from mass demonstrations in 2011, the one authoritarian regime survived, while the other experienced a transition. Since 2011, movements associated with social and labor policies have benefitted more from redistributive policies in the authoritarian case than in the democratizing case. This finding represents a puzzle that motivates this proposal. In this study, the PI seeks to learn how regime transition in developing countries influences the success of social movements to win redistributive concessions from the government. Additionally, the work will investigate the characteristics of political movements that determine whether the state will or will not respond to their demands. To assess these questions, the PI will construct a dataset of local-level protests from two countries in a key part of the world.

Technical
In this proposal, the PI seeks to investigate how social movement groups succeed or fail in their ability to win redistributive policy concessions from the state. In particular, the PI seeks to address two particular research goals. First, she aims to trace changes in socioeconomic mobilization in two countries from 2005 to 2015, paying particular attention to shifts in the frequency, diffusion, organization, and repertoires of protest movements. Second, given these patterns, the project seeks to account for trends in social policy responses that do not comply with existing theoretical expectations. The PI argues that patterns of redistributive policy concessions differ depending upon the success or failure of social movements seeking democracy. With respect to successful democratizing revolutions, we find an amplification of the characteristics expected to lead to greater state responses, i.e. the frequency, diffusion, and organization of socioeconomic mobilization. In 'failed' revolutions, however, the perceptions of threat experienced by the political elites leads them to grant policy concessions more quickly when faced with protest movements. The project develops a multi-method research design in which the PI proposes to construct original datasets of protest events and corresponding state response in two countries during the period 2005 to 2015. These datasets will be constructed using a range of local newspapers. Next, the PI will undertake qualitative comparative studies of parallel social movements in both cases. This project will result in the completion of a database that catalogues protests, strikes, sit-ins, and violent events on a national level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This National Science Foundation award contributed to the collection of two original datasets. Morocco Contentious Event Dataset (MCED) and Tunisia Contentious Event Dataset (TCED) catalog contemporary protests, sit-ins, strikes, and violent events as reported in range of local Arabic- and French-language publications. These datasets contain detailed information pertaining to the demands, tactics, sectors, and organizations involved in protest actions, and pertaining to state response in the form of repression and concessions to protest. They provide a unique fine-grain view of routine contention and response on a subnational level, going beyond the major political protests that may break into international headlines. These data were collected to support a range of empirical projects pertaining to the causes and consequences of popular mobilization in contemporary North Africa.

 

More specifically from a substantive perspective, these data are currently being used to test and demonstrate the effects of revolutions – both “successful” and failed – on state response to socioeconomic protest events. Where party systems and welfare institutions are weak or co-opted, protest movements become a primary means by which citizens make distributive demands on the state. Nearly eighty percent of protests in the MCED and TCED sample advance socioeconomic demands. This analysis finds that "failed" revolutions – such as Morocco's experience duing the 2011 Arab Uprisings – lead to patterns of higher concessions to socioeconomic protest, as surviving elites use social concessions to demobilize mass opposition while avoiding political reforms. In cases of successful revolution and democratization – namely Tunisia – the opposite occurs. While the absence of coercion in a democratic context encourages protest, elites in this contest no longer uniformly aim to demobilize protest movements in service of regime longevity. Instead, this project finds that imperatives of coalition-building in a new democracy prompt elites to undermine opponents' attempts at social negotiation and to channel exclusive concessions to smaller, well-organized protest groups who may lend political support.

 

In theoretical terms, these findings contribute to a large and important literature in comparative politics considering the relationship between regime type and redistribution by addressing the question of many why contemporary democratic transitions – despite prevailing expectations – fall short of redressing popular claims for economic opportunity and social protection. These findings also contribute to an important literature on authoritarian resilience and redistribution in a non-democratic setting, illuminating one important mechanism by which non-democratic regimes may increase social spending.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/17/2018
Modified by: Amaney Jamal
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This National Science Foundation award contributed to the collection of two original datasets. Morocco Contentious Event Dataset (MCED) and Tunisia Contentious Event Dataset (TCED) catalog contemporary protests, sit-ins, strikes, and violent events as reported in range of local Arabic- and French-language publications. These datasets contain detailed information pertaining to the demands, tactics, sectors, and organizations involved in protest actions, and pertaining to state response in the form of repression and concessions to protest. They provide a unique fine-grain view of routine contention and response on a subnational level, going beyond the major political protests that may break into international headlines. These data were collected to support a range of empirical projects pertaining to the causes and consequences of popular mobilization in contemporary North Africa. More specifically from a substantive perspective, these data are currently being used to test and demonstrate the effects of revolutions – both "successful" and failed – on state response to socioeconomic protest events. Where party systems and welfare institutions are weak or co-opted, protest movements become a primary means by which citizens make distributive demands on the state. Nearly eighty percent of protests in the MCED and TCED sample advance socioeconomic demands. This analysis finds that "failed" revolutions – such as Morocco's experience duing the 2011 Arab Uprisings – lead to patterns of higher concessions to socioeconomic protest, as surviving elites use social concessions to demobilize mass opposition while avoiding political reforms. In cases of successful revolution and democratization – namely Tunisia – the opposite occurs. While the absence of coercion in a democratic context encourages protest, elites in this contest no longer uniformly aim to demobilize protest movements in service of regime longevity. Instead, this project finds that imperatives of coalition-building in a new democracy prompt elites to undermine opponents' attempts at social negotiation and to channel exclusive concessions to smaller, well-organized protest groups who may lend political support. In theoretical terms, these findings contribute to a large and important literature in comparative politics considering the relationship between regime type and redistribution by addressing the question of many why contemporary democratic transitions – despite prevailing expectations – fall short of redressing popular claims for economic opportunity and social protection. These findings also contribute to an important literature on authoritarian resilience and redistribution in a non-democratic setting, illuminating one important mechanism by which non-democratic regimes may increase social spending.
